content:
Thomas Hart is a graduate student of computational biology in the Krumsiek Lab at the Weill Cornell Medical Center. His current research projects are focused on characterizing the tumor microenvironment of prostate cancer using spatial metabolomics and developing performant visualization methods to efficiently describe high dimensional data. More broadly, his research interests include multiomic integration, data fusion methods, and literate programming for efficiently distributing scientific knowledge. Thomas actively supports open source science by frequently publishing packages in a variety of languages to various repositories including github and CRAN.
Outside of his research, Thomas can be found hiking in the nearest mountains, looking for the next best burger or taking in shows on Broadway. He actively works to pass on these passions to others through his work with the National Ski Patrol and National Park Service, No Kid Hungry, and supporting Broadway actors via The Actors Fund.
summary: Thomas Hart is a graduate student of computational biology in the Krumsiek Lab at the Weill Cornell Medical Center. summary: Patients with resected stage II-III melanoma have approximately a 35% chance of death from their disease. A deeper understanding of the tumor immune microenvironment (TIME) is required to stratify patients and identify factors leading to therapy resistance. We previously identified that the melanoma immune profile (MIP), an IFN-based gene signature, and the ratio of CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) ...
title: Linking Transcriptomic and Imaging Data Defines Features of a Favorable Tumor Immune Microenvironment and Identifies a Combination Biomarker for Primary Melanoma

summary: Novel methods to analyze the tumor microenvironment (TME) are urgently needed to stratify melanoma patients for adjuvant immunotherapy. Tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) analysis, by conventional pathologic methods, is predictive but is insufficiently precise for clinical application. Quantitative multiplex immunofluorescence (qmIF) allows for evaluation of the TME using multiparameter ...
title: Quantitative Analysis of Immune Infiltrates in Primary Melanoma

summary: Immunotherapy, in particular checkpoint blockade, has changed the clinical landscape of metastatic melanoma. Nonetheless, the majority of patients will either be primary refractory or progress over follow up. Management of patients progressing on first-line immunotherapy remains challenging. Expanded treatment options with combination immunotherapy has demonstrated efficacy in patients ...
title: Complete intracranial response to talimogene laherparepvec (T-Vec), pembrolizumab and whole brain radiotherapy in a patient with melanoma brain metastases refractory to dual checkpoint-inhibition
